Award.AwardTitle: BCC-SBE/EHR: Developing Community & Capacity to Measure Noncognitive Factors in Digital Learning Environments

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers from SRI International are building a collaborative research community to support the measurement of noncognitive factors associated with learning in science, technology, engineering and mathematics using data from digital learning environments. Constructs such as engagement, grit, tenacity and perseverance are examined as they are strong predictors of academic outcomes. The project uses an evidence-centered design to provide a structured approach for assessing these hard to measure constructs. Products from the research include a detailed framework and shared worked examples that can be used to build common measurement approaches. In addition, the project builds the capacity for a community of software developers, learning science researchers and measurement specialists to work together to expand what is known about how to integrate cognitive and noncognitive outcomes in digital learning environments.

The focus of this work is the use of a framework for assessment called evidence-centered design (ECD). ECD is well suited to supporting the development of rigorous measures of noncognitive assessments as it supports researchers in identifying where and how such constructs are manifested in digital learning environments. The researchers from SRI leverage the infrastructure for learning resource analytics (the Learning Registry) that they have developed to create a content-distribution and replication network to support the work of the community that they are building in this project. White papers from the workshops articulate the research agenda that the digitial learning environment research community is developing. Two workshops support the efforts to develop the worked examples of the measurement of noncognitive outcomes and five knowledge community building sessions, as preconference workshops and symposia, provide a dissemination mechanism to support bringing additional researchers into this community.

This project builds strongly on the previous work that has been conducted by SRI and by the researchers they intend to include in the community for which they are building capacity. The digital learning environments that are the focus of the worked examples of the connection of noncognitive and cognitive factors represent a strong set of the projects that have been funded by NSF. They are the learning environments that are most prevalent in the research and development environment in the STEM digital learning environment and include other digital environments, such as the Khan Academy, that are widely used in education. With the growing interest in college and career ready standards and the emphasis on workforce development skills that emphasize soft skills, the project brings together a community of researchers around a common, important problem.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this project was to build a community of researchers—referred to as the Analytics for Learning (A4L) network—and to develop the skills of community members around using data from digital learning environments to measure learning strategies and behaviors. To support network-building efforts, we used the assessment framework known as Evidence-Centered Design (ECD). ECD is an approach that helps in building valid measures by focusing on the ways in which evidence drawn from learning tasks can be used to measure knowledge and abilities. The A4L network used ECD as a common set of tools and processes around which to bring diverse researchers together.

Throughout this project, we connected junior and senior researchers through a variety of different approaches, such as hand-on workshops and innovative collaborative data analysis activities. For example, in our first workshop, we organized leading researchers from different educational research fields to co-develop potential measures using ECD. Following this workshop, we formed partnerships with leading research organizations (e.g., Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching) as well as other NSF-sponsored community and capacity building projects (e.g., Play Data Consortium based at the University of Wisconsin, Madison). Through a partnership with the Carnegie Foundation, we developed new ways of using data from digital learning environments to drive continuous improvement processes in schools and universities.

The A4L network seeded the development of dozens of “design patterns.” Based in ECD, design patterns are high-level operationalizations of learning behaviors that can be shared across interested researchers. Along with seeding the development of multiple design patterns, the A4L network hosted multiple hands-on workshops as well as forums for researchers in academia and industry. Workshops and presentations brought together researchers who would later go on to publish research articles and launch federally funded projects through the connections they made as part of the A4L network. One workshop involved pairing senior and junior researchers to engage in joint data analysis using data from digital learning environments. Feedback from those who participated in the workshop highlighted the uniqueness of the event and the overall benefit that the opportunity to learn alongside experts provided junior researchers in accelerating their work. Another innovative way of bringing senior and junior researchers together in the service of building the A4L network included a “white paper” series where junior researchers worked with their faculty advisors and researchers from SRI International to use ECD in their research.

Based on the successes of our efforts to build a network of researchers and to support researchers in developing new skills, this project connected multiple researchers and organizations. Across multiple activities, this project demonstrated that ECD could be used to reverse engineer and find value in data already being collected by a digital learning environment. Typically, ECD is described as a process where researchers and domain experts design new learning environments. Through this project, we provided one potential path by which researchers and technology developers can unlock the potential of data collected by multiple digital learning environments to understand student learning in new ways.
